Message.Title: ***Strongest International Currency, Economy, Sector, and Stock***
Message.Msg: The strongest international currency right now is the New Zealand Dollar, which rose over $0.01 to $0.84 last night vs. the U.S. dollar. New Zealand has the fastest growing GDP out of all advanced economies and the lowest unemployment rate! New Zealand's agricultural sector is booming as China's rising middle class is causing food prices to rise very rapidly. Large Asian agricultural companies are now entering bidding wars to acquire New Zealand/Australian agricultural companies - and the share prices of New Zealand/Australian agricultural stocks are soaring. Agria (NYSE: GRO) saw this HUGE mega trend coming back in 2011 and was the first to acquire a controlling stake in a major New Zealand agricultural company. GRO's Agria Asia subsidiary now owns 379.1 million shares of PGG Wrightson (PGW.NZ)'s 754.85 million shares outstanding - for a 50.22% stake in the company. GRO sold off two small pieces of Agria Asia to help fund its acquisition of 50.22% of PGW, including the sale of 11.95% of Agria Asia to New Hope for USD$20 million. GRO retained 80.81% of Agria Asia for itself. New Hope is a $8.8 billion revenue Chinese agricultural company and their $20 million purchase price for 11.95% of Agria Asia values GRO's 80.81% at $135.25 million. GRO only has 55.38 million shares outstanding, which means based on New Hope's purchase price - GRO should be worth $2.44 per share. PGW closed last night on the New Zealand Exchange at an eight month high of $0.43 per share valuing Agria Asia's shares at NZ$163.013 million or USD$137.012 million. This means GRO's 80.81% of Agria Asia has a current market value of USD$110.72 million. With 55.38 million shares outstanding, GRO deserves to be trading immediately for a minimum of $2 per share. A 45%-77% rally for GRO to $2-$2.44 per share could be imminent! PGG Wrightson has been in business for 160 years and is the largest seed company in New Zealand/Australia! We own 550,000 shares of GRO and intend to sell at much higher prices

Message.Title: I guess not likely to raise the dividend next year either after the next
Message.Msg: round of stress tests. It was anticipated they would raise to at least .20 annual this year, but instead they did the small share buy back. Seems rather than the potential law suits declining, and potential liability shrinking, it is going in the other direction. Instead of a 5 year window for law suits the GOV juiced it to 10. I am long bac, but at this point starting to think it is not worth holding. SO tell me I am WRONG please. Any dividend raise in 2014 will get this stock to start a slow climb back to PEER level, that has been the thought that keeps me ignoring the current weakness.

Topic.Title: I guess not likely to raise the dividend next year either after the next

Message.Msg: That is a decision only you can make. Whether or not BAC asks for a dividend increase next year is something only they know. All anyone on this board can do is make a guess. Based on the trash talk that takes place on this board, I'd be very, very careful about taking anyone's advice. However, if you are truly long as you state, I can't imagine why you wouldn't wait until we find out for sure what they are looking to do with the dividend/share buybacks for next year. In my opinion BAC has already shown they can weather the legal landscape even if the issues last longer than originally expected. There any knock out blows in anything I've seen so far.
Like OXBT it will not happen in immediately....

Topic.Title: I guess not likely to raise the dividend next year either after the next

Message.Msg: Hard to think shareholders will see much of the profits, either through dividends or buybacks in the near future. The last stress tests set up a very dire economic scenario and while it's hard to believe this new stress test will set up much worse conditions, the new stress tests may do just that requiring greater capital adequacy. The irony is that as greater capital would be required under the new stress tests, the DoJ is extorting mass amounts of capital from the big banks with endless fines, penalties, etc. In short, banks are operating in a #$%$ political, regulatory and economic environment for which there is no short term solution. But BAC has the capacity under normal conditions to earn $2.25 - $2.50 per share on its existing assets and capital structure. And it will eventually achieve that profitablility. So whether you hold or not is soley dependent on your time frame.

Topic.Title: ACA

Message.Msg: Myth: Obamacare is leading to part-time jobs It's a common refrain of its opponents: Obamacare will force struggling Americans into part-time work. Well, the first bits of evidence have come in, and it does not look as if the Affordable Care Act has had any negative impact on full-time work. Between August and September the economy has added 691,000 full-time jobs, while it has lost 594,000 part-time jobs, according to the September jobs report. While this is only one month's worth of data, it indicates that at least so far, the law hasn't pushed full-time employees into part-time work.

Message.Title: P/E
Message.Msg: About once every 2 or 3 weeks I check out various banks that I own P/E's just for the fun of it. Has anyone noticed how BAC's is slowly but surely trending down? Nice move down this month. Finally in the low 20's! Before we know it it will be a normal 10-12 Bank P/E and the major litigation will be behind us, earnings will be up Big Time and so will the share price! It is sneaking up quietly and if you don't get in in next 6 months or less, it will be too late. 6 months - $20/18months - $26-28. My opinion! Before someone says I am stupid - I check my P/E's on my Tech and other stocks daily!!!! Along with all other data available. Not necessary on Banks.
